message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inulin is a fructose polysaccharide that is not metabolized by the body and only filtered in the glomerulus but not reabsorbed, secreted, or metabolized. It is thus a suitable tracer for measuring extracellular fluid volume. Albumin and urea are both metabolized, and heavy water can cross the cellular membranes, making them unsuitable for this purpose.

We refer to the article “Measurement of Body Fluid Compartments” by J.E. Sharpey-Schafer for help. Among the options, only inulin is a tracer that is capillary membrane permeable but impermeable to cellular membranes. This makes it suitable for measuring extracellular fluid volume. Albumin is not completely impermeable to cellular membranes, heavy water is not permeable to capillary membranes, and urea is permeable to both capillary and cellular membranes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question asks for a tracer that is permeable to the capillary membrane but not to cellular membranes. Among the options, only inulin is known to fit this description as it is freely filtered by the glomerulus, but it does not undergo reabsorption or secretion by the renal tubules. As a result, it remains inside the extracellular fluid and can be used to measure extracellular fluid volume. The other options have limitations in terms of permeability or specificity to the fluid compartment of interest.

We refer to the following source for help: "Physiology, Renal Function". Among the options, only inulin is completely filtered by the glomerulus, is not reabsorbed, secreted, or metabolized, and is therefore a reliable indicator of glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and plasma volume. It meets the requirement of being capillary membrane permeable but impermeable to cellular membranes, making it the most suitable tracer for measuring the volume of a specific body fluid compartment. Albumin is a protein and cannot completely diffuse through the capillary membrane, making it unsuitable. Heavy water (D2O) and urea are permeable through both capillary and cellular membranes, making them unsuitable as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, inulin is the most suitable tracer for measuring extracellular fluid volume as it has the required properties of being freely filtered at the glomerulus and completely excluded from both intracellular and extracellular proteins. Heavy water (D2O) can be used to measure total body water, urea can be used to measure blood flow, and albumin can be used to measure plasma volume, but none of those options meet the requirements of being capillary membrane permeable but impermeable to cellular membranes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only inulin is suitable for the researcher's experiment. It meets the requirements of being capillary membrane permeable and impermeable to cellular membranes. Albumin and urea are both permeable to cellular membranes, while heavy water (D2O) is not capillary membrane permeable.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. For this experiment, a tracer that is capillary membrane permeable but impermeable to cellular membranes is needed. Among the options, inulin is the most suitable tracer as it is freely filtered at the glomerulus and is not secreted or reabsorbed by the tubules. Therefore, it stays in the extracellular fluid and can be used to measure plasma volume or extracellular fluid volume. Albumin is also capillary membrane permeable, but it can bind to intravascular proteins and therefore may not give accurate measurements. Heavy water and urea are not capillary membrane permeable.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inulin is an ideal tracer for measuring extracellular fluid volume because it is small enough to pass through capillary membranes but too large to cross cell membranes. This means that it remains in the extracellular fluid compartment and does not diffuse into cells. Albumin is also capillary membrane permeable but may also be taken up by cells. Heavy water and urea are not specific to extracellular fluid and may also distribute to intracellular or other fluid compartments.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, inulin is the most suitable tracer as it is freely filtered by the renal glomerulus, and it is only minimally reabsorbed or secreted by the renal tubule. It is inert and does not bind to plasma proteins or cellular membranes, making it a good indicator of extracellular volume.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inulin is the best tracer for measuring extracellular fluid volume because it is a small, inert molecule that is freely filtered by the glomerulus and is neither reabsorbed nor secreted by the renal tubules. It is capillary membrane permeable but cannot cross cellular membranes, making it an excellent tracer for extracellular fluid volume measurement. Albumin is also capillary membrane permeable but it is actively transported across cell membranes, which makes it unsuitable for this experiment. Heavy water and urea, on the other hand, are not capillary membrane permeable, which also makes them unsuitable as tracers.
